Catalytic hydrogenolysis of lignin to high value-added chemicals has been a hot topic in recent years. Metal oxide catalysts are prepared by the co-precipitation method. Bi₂O₃ exhibits unique advantages in catalyzing lignin depolymerization for bio-oil production, demonstrating high selectivity in cleaving ether bonds within the lignin structure.The purpose of this study is to compare the performance of bismuth metal with several other metals for the catalytic hydrogenolysis of lignin. Based on the response surface methodology (RSM), the catalytic abilities of several metal oxides for the preparation of bio-oil from lignin under optimal conditions were determined as follows: NiO (77.18 wt %) ≈ Bi₂O₃ (77.04 wt %) > Co₃O₄ (71.12 wt %) > CeO₂ (61.39 wt %); However, comparable performance can be achieved with significantly lower amounts of Bi₂O₃ catalysts. Gas chromatography-mass spectrometry (GC–MS) analysis demonstrated that Bi₂O₃-catalyzed product contained 66.45 wt % yield of phenolic compounds, significantly higher than those catalyzed by other metal oxides. Notably, the combined yield of creosol (G2) and vanillin (G3) reached 21.36 wt %, representing the highest value among all catalysts tested. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) spectra showed that the components in the lignin depolymerization system were uniformly dispersed in the presence of Bi₂O₃ catalyst, which contributed to the cleavage of ether bonds and promoted the generation of a large amount of phenolic compounds. The interactive effects of temperature, time and catalyst dosage on the catalytic hydrogenolysis of lignin and the effect of the addition of the hydrogen donor, formic acid, on the depolymerization were also analyzed. Finally, the recoverability test showed that the catalytic performance of Bi₂O₃ remained active and stable after five consecutive recovery runs. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Lignin-catalyzed hydrogenolysis Metal oxides Metal catalysts Comparison of depolymerization effects Bio-oil yield Phenolic compounds Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Energy resources, from primitive biomass to modern fossil fuels (coal, petroleum, natural gas), are pivotal to human civilization. Nevertheless, finite resource availability contrasts sharply with ever-increasing global energy demands. Current ecological crises, particularly climate change, underscore the critical need for establishing sustainable energy systems characterized by environmental friendliness, carbon neutrality, energy security, and operational efficiency [1,2]. Among renewable alternatives, bioenergy emerges as a strategic solution to address multiple challenges: reducing reliance on conventional fossil fuels, mitigating environmental contamination, optimizing energy infrastructure, and supporting carbon neutrality objectives [3]. As a carbon-neutral energy carrier, bioenergy presents a viable substitute for conventional energy sources [4]. Within this context, lignin has garnered significant research interest owing to its widespread availability and cost-effectiveness. The valorization of this abundant biopolymer offers dual benefits: addressing environmental concerns associated with pulp industry effluents while creating value-added products such as oilfield chemicals, agricultural amendments, and industrial additives. When utilized for bioenergy generation, lignin contributes to energy autonomy while simultaneously addressing carbon emission concerns [5–7]. Lignin depolymerization yields phenolic-rich bio-oils with high-value components that have great potential in several industries. These aromatic compounds, especially guaiacyl-type (G-type) phenolics, have significant bioactivity and chemical versatility with important applications in energy, materials and pharmaceuticals. Phenolic compounds, which can be used as natural preservatives and drug intermediates, replace synthetic additives in the food, cosmetic and pharmaceutical industries [8,9]. Creosol has excellent bactericidal activity and is often used in medical disinfection products to ensure public health and safety; in the chemical field, it is used as a synthetic raw material, participating in the production of resins and plasticizers. Vanillin, which accounts for 65 % of the global bio-based flavors market, has become an indispensable flavor in the food, cosmetic and pharmaceutical industries due to its unique and rich aroma; it is widely used in pastries and beverages to enhance the flavor of products, add pleasant aroma to perfumes and skin care products, and mask the bad smell of medicines to improve the experience of taking medicines, and at the same time, it also has antioxidant and neuroprotective activities [10]. Phenolic hydroxyl and methoxy groups give them active sites, enabling the preparation of bio-based polymeric materials such as epoxy resins, cyanate esters, benzoxazine resins, and polycarbonate precursors through etherification, esterification, and other reactions [11,12]. In addition, phenolics can be used as green platform compounds, which can be converted into high-grade hydrocarbon fuels by hydrodeoxygenation to enhance the energy density of bio-oil [13]. The efficient utilization of phenolics from lignin depolymerization products will not only add value to bio-sourced materials, but also effectively reduce the consumption of petroleum resources and mitigate environmental pollution, and its potential for replacing petroleum-based chemicals has received widespread attention [14]. The efficient conversion of lignin into valuable aromatic hydrocarbons as potential substitutes for conventional fossil fuels remains a prominent research focus in sustainable energy development. A critical challenge in lignin valorization involves the undesirable recombination of reactive intermediates during depolymerization, which significantly compromises product yields. Catalytic hydrodepolymerization has emerged as an effective strategy to address this limitation, with substantial experimental evidence demonstrating that appropriate catalyst systems can simultaneously enhance both reaction efficiency and product stability [15]. Recent advances have identified several transition metals capable of selectively cleaving the characteristic ether linkages in lignin polymers. Particularly noteworthy is the performance of cobalt-based catalysts, where optimal deposition (15 wt %) on modified ATP supports at 220 °C achieves remarkable lignin conversion rates (87.15 wt %) with bio-oil yields reaching 63.1 wt % [16]. In parallel developments, cerium-containing bimetallic systems have demonstrated exceptional potential, as evidenced by Chen et al.'s work on Ce-based MOF catalysts [17]. The synergistic interaction between cerium and cobalt in these systems facilitates electron transfer processes, generating abundant oxygen vacancies that significantly improve hydrodeoxygenation efficiency for both lignin-derived phenolics and macromolecular fragments. Nickel-based catalysts have also shown outstanding performance in lignin hydrogenolysis. Ewuzie et al. developed bimetallic Ni-Co/C and Ni-Cu/C systems that exhibit enhanced hydrogen transfer capability in isopropanol-mediated depolymerization [18]. Under optimized conditions, the Ni-Co/C catalyst achieved exceptional results, including 94.2 % lignin conversion and 53.1 wt % monomer yield, highlighting the potential of cost-effective non-precious metal catalysts for industrial-scale lignin valorization. Recent studies have demonstrated the outstanding photocatalytic performance of bismuth-containing materials, attributed to their distinctive layered configurations and optimal electronic band structures. These photocatalysts primarily include bismuth oxides, sulfides, halides, and oxyacid salts, among others [19–21]. Particularly noteworthy is bismuth trioxide (Bi₂O₃), an environmentally benign semiconductor material that exists in six crystalline polymorphs with adjustable bandgap energies ranging from 2.0 to 3.96 electron volts [22]. This versatile material has gained significant research interest for its effectiveness in decomposing various organic contaminants. The application of bismuth-based composite materials in light-driven lignin depolymerization has achieved substantial progress in contemporary research [23]. Recent advances in bismuth-catalyzed lignin hydrogenolysis have elucidated two complementary mechanistic pathways. Zhang et al. demonstrated that Bi₂O₃'s strong Lewis acidity preferentially cleaves β-O-4 linkages via phenoxide intermediates with 85 % conversion efficiency [24], while Wang et al. revealed that mobile lattice oxygen in BixOy frameworks facilitates simultaneous H₂ dissociation and CO bond scission, suppressing char formation [25]. This study investigated the catalytic performance of bismuth-based materials in lignin hydrogenolysis. To systematically evaluate their effectiveness, we synthesized various metal oxide catalysts (Bi₂O₃, NiO, Co₃O₄, and CeO₂) through a co-precipitation approach. Supercritical alcohols serve as effective hydrogen sources in this system, providing hydrogen species through multiple pathways: molecular hydrogen (H₂), hydride ions (H⁻), and protons (H⁺). These reactive hydrogen species originate from α-hydrogen atoms and hydroxyl groups of the alcohol molecules, concurrently generating various byproducts including hydroxyalkylated compounds, alkoxide ions, and electron-deficient aldehydes [26]. In our experimental design, ethanol was selected as the primary hydrogen donor, supplemented with 2 mL of formic acid as an additional proton source. The reaction parameters were carefully optimized through the response surface methodology (RSM) approach, examining three key variables: temperature (180–240 °C), duration (2–10 h), and catalyst loading (4–20 %, relative to the mass of lignin). This statistical optimisation allowed the determination of the maximum lignin conversion efficiency and bio-oil production yield for each catalyst system. This allowed direct comparison of the catalytic performance of Bi₂O₃ with other metal oxides. Comprehensive characterization of the depolymerization products was conducted using GC–MS to identify bio-oil components. The morphological and structural changes in the lignin fragments were analyzed through SEM and FT-IR. These analytical techniques provided insights into the depolymerization mechanism and product distribution. Finally, we evaluated the individual and combined effects of critical process parameters including reaction temperature, time duration, Bi₂O₃ catalyst concentration, and hydrogen donor composition on the overall depolymerization efficiency. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Materials Alkali lignin was purchased from TCL (Shanghai) Development Co., Ltd. Its compositions were analyzed on the Vario MACRO cube elemental analyzer. Contents (wt %) of C, H, N, and O (by difference) were 42.96, 5.48, 5.23, and 46.33 %, respectively; the empirical formula was C3.58H5.23O2.9N0.37. Bismuth nitrate pentahydrate (Bi(NO3)3·5H2O, 99.99 %), nickel nitrate hexahydrate (Ni(NO3)2·6H2O, 99 %), cobalt nitrate hexahydrate (Co(NO3)2·6H2O, 99 %), cerium nitrate hexahydrate (Ce(NO3)3·6H2O, 99.99 %), anhydrous sodium carbonate (Na2CO3), anhydrous ethanol (C2H5OH), formic acid, dilute hydrochloric acid (HCl, 37 %), nitric acid, sodium hydroxide (NaOH, AR, 96 %) and ethyl acetate (CH3COOCH2CH3, AR, 99 %) were purchased from Nanjing Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. (Nanjing, China). All reagents were used as received. 2.2 Catalyst preparation Synthesis of Bi₂O₃: The preparation process commenced by dissolving 3 mmol of bismuth nitrate pentahydrate (Bi(NO₃)₃·5H₂O) in 6 mL of 1 mol/L nitric acid solution under continuous magnetic stirring, yielding a homogeneous mixture designated as Solution A. Concurrently, Solution B was prepared by dissolving 15 mmol of sodium carbonate (Na₂CO₃) in 20 mL of deionized water with vigorous agitation until complete dissolution was achieved. The synthesis proceeded by gradually introducing Solution A into Solution B under controlled conditions, and then continuously stirred for 1 h to ensure thorough reaction. The resulting suspension was subjected to thermal treatment at 80 °C for 4 h to promote precipitation. Subsequent purification involved repeated washing cycles, alternating between deionized water and absolute ethanol (three times each), to remove residual impurities. The intermediate product, bismuth subcarbonate (Bi₂O₂CO₃, abbreviated as BOC), was obtained after drying the washed precipitate at 80 °C for 12 h. Thermal conversion of BOC to the final product was accomplished through calcination in a covered crucible. The temperature was systematically increased to 500 °C at a controlled heating rate of 10 °C per min in a muffle furnace, followed by isothermal treatment for 4 h. After natural cooling to ambient temperature, the calcined material was carefully collected and mechanically ground using an agate mortar to produce finely divided Bi₂O₃ powder. Preparation of other metal oxides: Taking Co3O4 as an example: The fabrication of Co₃O₄ was carried out through a precipitation method. Initially, 3.5 g of cobalt(II) nitrate hexahydrate (Co(NO₃)₂·6H₂O) was completely dissolved in 60 mL of distilled water under constant agitation at ambient temperature for 10 min, forming a clear solution (denoted as Solution A). In parallel, an aqueous solution of sodium carbonate (Solution B) was prepared by dissolving 2 g of Na₂CO₃ in 20 mL of deionized water with magnetic stirring until complete dissolution was achieved. The synthesis proceeded by dropwise addition of Solution A into Solution B under controlled conditions, followed by continuous mechanical stirring for 1 h to ensure homogeneous mixing and complete precipitation. The obtained slurry was then subjected to thermal aging at 80 °C for 4 h to enhance crystallinity. The aged precipitate underwent sequential purification steps including vacuum filtration, followed by thorough washing cycles using both deionized water and absolute ethanol to remove ionic impurities. The purified intermediate was subsequently dried at 80 °C for 12 h to obtain the precursor material. Thermal transformation to the final product was achieved through controlled calcination in a muffle furnace, employing a heating program with a constant ramp rate of 10 °C per min up to 500 °C, followed by a 4 h isothermal treatment. The resulting product was confirmed to be phase-pure Co₃O₄ through subsequent characterization. 2.3 Catalyst characterization X-ray diffraction analysis was performed using a D/max2550VB/PC diffractometer equipped with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5406 Å). The measurements were conducted over a 2θ range of 5–100° with a scanning speed of 4° per minute. The instrument was operated at 40 kV accelerating voltage and 100 mA tube current to ensure optimal signal intensity. Fourier-transform infrared spectroscopy characterization was carried out on a Nicolet 3800 spectrometer (Thermo Scientific, USA). The spectral data were collected in the mid-infrared region (4000–400 cm⁻¹) with 4 cm⁻¹ resolution. For sample preparation, each catalyst was uniformly mixed with potassium bromide (KBr) at an appropriate ratio to ensure proper light transmission during analysis. 2.4 Depolymerization of lignin The catalytic depolymerization studies were conducted in a 100 mL stainless steel batch reactor system without agitation capability. The reaction procedure involved initially loading 0.5 g of alkaline lignin along with varying catalyst quantities (4–20 %) into the PTFE reactor insert. To this mixture, 50 mL of absolute ethanol and 2 mL of formic acid were added as the solvent system and hydrogen donor respectively, followed by vigorous mixing to ensure complete dispersion of all components. The sealed reactor assembly was then heated to predetermined temperatures ranging from 180 to 240 °C and maintained at these conditions for reaction periods between 2 and 10 h. Upon completion of the thermal treatment, rapid quenching was achieved using an ice-water bath to terminate the reaction. The product distribution comprised gaseous, liquid and solid fractions. However, the minimal gas yield (< 0.5 wt %) precluded its detailed analysis in the current investigation. Product workup commenced with vacuum filtration to effect solid-liquid separation. The reactor liner underwent three successive washings with 25 mL aliquots of ethyl acetate to facilitate complete extraction of lignin-derived compounds. The combined liquid fractions were concentrated using rotary evaporation at 60 °C to isolate the bio-oil product after solvent removal. For catalyst recovery, the solid residue was treated with 0.025 mol/L sodium hydroxide solution to separate unconverted lignin through acid-base fractionation. Subsequent acidification with HCl precipitated the unreacted lignin, while the catalyst and coke fractions were recovered by drying at 105 °C for 12 h prior to characterization 2.5 Product characterization RSM was employed to investigate the effects of different metal oxide catalyst temperatures, reaction times and catalyst amounts on the yield response (Y) of bio-oil from the catalytic depolymerization of lignin. The ranges of temperature, reaction time and additive amount are shown in Table 1 . Seventeen depolymerization experiments were generated using a three-factor Box-Behnken Design (BBD, Design-Expert13 software, Stat-Ease, Inc. USA) with the specific scheme shown in Table 2 . 3D Surfaces were finally generated to obtain the highest bio-oil yields of different metal oxides at optimal parameters. In order to verify the accuracy of the model, three sets of parallel experiments were conducted based on the optimal process conditions described above. Bio-oil compositional analysis was performed using gas chromatography-mass spectrometry (GC–MS) with a Trace Ultra GC system interfaced with a DSQ II mass selective detector. Prior to analysis, samples were prepared by dissolving in HPLC-grade methanol at a ratio of 1:1 (v/v), achieving a final concentration of 0.05 mg/mL. A 1 μL aliquot was injected into the GC system under helium carrier gas flowing at 1 mL/min. The oven temperature protocol consisted of an initial isothermal period at 50 °C for 60 s, followed by two consecutive heating phases: the first ramping at 8 °C/min to 220 °C with a 1-min hold, and the second increasing at 10 °C/min to a final temperature of 300 °C. Morphological characterization of lignin and solid pyrolysis products was conducted using a VLTRA55 field emission scanning electron microscope (Carl Zeiss SMT, Germany). For chemical structure analysis, Fourier-transform infrared spectra were acquired with a Nicolet 3800 spectrometer (Thermo Scientific, USA) operating at 4 cm⁻¹ resolution across the 4000–400 cm⁻¹ range. Sample preparation for FTIR involved thorough mixing with spectroscopic-grade potassium bromide powder to ensure proper spectral quality. The quantification of reaction products, including gaseous components, solid residues, bio-oil, and principal phenolic compounds, was performed using mathematical expressions (Eqs. (1)–(4)) to determine their respective yields. (1) T h e y i e l d o f b i o − o i l ( wt % ) = m 1 m 0 × 100 % (2) T h e y i e l d o f c h a r ( wt % ) = m 2 m 0 × 100 % (3) T h e y i e l d o f u n r e a c t e d l i g n i n ( wt % ) = m 3 m 0 × 100 % (4) T h e y i e l d o f p h e n o l i c p r o d u c t ( wt % ) = m i m 0 × 100 % where m0 is the initial mass of lignin, m1 is the mass of bio-oil, m2 is the mass of charcoal, m3 is the mass of unreacted lignin, and mi is the mass of the major phenolic monomers (determined by GC-FID). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization The crystalline structures and phase purity of various metal oxide catalysts synthesized via co-precipitation were characterized using XRD analysis. As depicted in Fig. 1 (a), distinct diffraction patterns were observed for each catalyst sample. For the CeO2 sample, prominent reflections were detected at 2θ angles of 28.60°, 33.16°, 47.46°, 56.35°, 59.17°, 69.43°, 76.68°, 79.07°, and 88.37°, which can be assigned to the (111), (200), (220), (311), (222), (400), (331), (420), and (422) crystallographic planes, respectively (JCPDS no.75–0390). The Co3O4 catalyst exhibited characteristic peaks at 31.31°, 36.86°, 38.57°, 44.85°, 55.67°, 59.36°, and 65.25°, corresponding to the (220), (311), (222), (400), (422), (511), and (440) lattice planes (JCPDS no.74–2120). Similarly, NiO demonstrated diffraction signals at 37.19°, 43.28°, 62.85°, 75.30°, 79.28°, and 94.95°, indicative of the (111), (200), (220), (311), (222) and (400) crystal facets (JCPDS no.44–1159). Notably, Bi2O3 displayed three major peaks at 27.41°, 33.16° and 46.36°, which were indexed to the (−121), (202) and (041) planes (JCPDS no.71–0465). These well-defined diffraction patterns confirm the successful synthesis of all four metal oxide catalysts with high phase purity [27–29]. The infrared spectra of several metal oxides show that the peaks are basically the same except for the characteristic peaks of several oxides, which indicates that they have similar chemical environments and high phase purity. Their bands around 1600 cm-1 and 3400 cm-1 are attributed to the OH bending and stretching vibrations of adsorbed water molecules, respectively. Their bands around 1390 cm-1 and 1040 cm-1 correspond to OC=O and CO stretching vibrations, respectively, which can be attributed to the adsorption on the catalyst surface of CO₂ from the air. The samples exhibit strong absorption peaks at 455 cm⁻¹ and 511 cm⁻¹, primarily attributed to the vibrational modes of Bi–O bonds. These peaks correspond to the characteristic absorptions of Bi₂O₃ and may contribute to its enhanced activation of the lignin β-O-4 bond. The vibrational peak at 480 cm-1 is the stretching vibrational mode of Ni-O. The peaks at 593 cm-1 and 671 cm-1 are attributed to the stretching vibration of Co2+ -O and Co3+ -O, respectively [30]. The stretching vibrational peaks of Ce-O appeared near 479 cm-1. The spectral similarity across most regions, combined with the appearance of unique metal-oxygen vibrations, provides compelling evidence for the successful synthesis of phase-pure metal oxide catalysts with well-defined surface properties. These results confirm the formation of distinct crystalline oxides through the employed synthetic approach. 3.2 Effects of different metal oxides on lignin depolymerization 3.2.1 Effects on bio-oil yield Table 2 presents the three-factor experiments regarding the catalytic hydrogenolysis of lignin by each of the four metal oxides. Table 3 shows the ANOVA of the RSM for the depolymerization of lignin catalyzed by several metal oxides. The low p-value (< 0.001) and high f-value (> 4) observed in the table indicate that all the developed RSM models are significant. The catalytic performance of various metal oxides in lignin hydrogenolysis was systematically evaluated through RSM (Table 4 ). The developed model demonstrated excellent predictive accuracy, as evidenced by high R² values and minimal differences (< 0.2) between adjusted and predicted R² values [31]. Under optimized reaction conditions considering temperature, duration, and catalyst loading, the bio-oil yields followed this order: NiO (77.18 wt %) ≈ Bi₂O₃ (77.04 wt %) > Co₃O₄ (71.12 wt %) > CeO₂ (61.39 wt %). Furthermore, three sets of parallel experiments were conducted for the reactions under several optimal conditions to verify the accuracy of the model. It is noteworthy that the catalytic efficiency of Bi₂O₃ was comparable to that of NiO, with both achieving bio-oil yields of approximately 77 wt %. However, Bi₂O₃ showed excellent operational advantages, requiring only one-third of the catalyst loading (5 %) of NiO (15 %) to achieve maximum catalytic performance under about the same reaction conditions. This remarkable catalytic activity under milder conditions suggests that bismuth-based catalysts hold great promise for lignin valorization. Further optimization of reaction parameters, particularly hydrogen donor selection, could potentially enhance bismuth's catalytic performance. The unique properties of bismuth catalysts, including their ability to suppress carbon deposition while promoting the formation of value-added bio-oil components, may substantially reduce production costs and improve economic viability for industrial-scale bio-oil production. These findings highlight bismuth as a highly promising candidate for sustainable lignin conversion technologies. 3.2.2 Effects on G-phenol content Bio-oils contain valuable phenolic compounds that serve as important precursors for manufacturing high-value products such as pharmaceutical intermediates, antioxidant additives, and aromatic substances [32]. Fig. 2 presents the GC–MS chromatograms of bio-oils obtained from lignin hydrogenolysis catalyzed by four different metal oxides. Quantitative analysis of the monomeric components was performed using the peak area normalization method, revealing that the phenolic constituents exclusively consisted of G-type phenolics. This selective formation of G-type phenolic compounds can be attributed to the preferential cleavage of β-O-4 linkages, the most abundant and labile bonds in lignin's structural framework, facilitated by the acid-base bifunctional sites of the metal oxide catalysts [33–35]. The catalytic process promotes the transformation of adjacent functional groups into stable phenolic intermediates that ultimately yield G-type derivatives. Table 5 systematically lists all identified G-type small molecules, including their chemical names, structural formulas, and corresponding peak areas for comprehensive comparison. Analysis of the bio-oil composition presented in Table 5 reveals that while the four metal oxide catalysts produced similar categories of G-type phenolic compounds, variations in product distribution were observed due to differences in catalyst properties and reaction mechanisms. The distinct surface acid-base characteristics, crystalline structures, and hydrogen-donating capacities of these metal oxides influenced their lignin adsorption and activation behaviors, consequently affecting both the variety and abundance of phenolic derivatives in the bio-oils. Notably, the CeO₂-catalyzed bio-oil uniquely was detected to contain trace amounts of 2‑methoxy-4-vinylphenol (G5). This specificity can be attributed to the exceptional oxygen storage capacity of CeO₂ and the abundance of oxygen vacancies, which facilitate the redox transformations of certain lignin functional groups. This therefore favours the formation of this particular compound [36]. Similarly, eugenol (G11) was exclusively detected in the Co₃O₄-catalyzed product, likely resulting from the catalyst's distinctive electronic configuration that enables valence changes during the reaction. This property facilitates oxidation of methoxy groups to hydroxyls while cleaving adjacent CC bonds, generating allyl-containing intermediates that ultimately yield eugenol [37]. With the exception of Co₃O₄, however, minor quantities of 3′‑hydroxy-5,6,7,4′-tetramethoxyflavone (G18) were detected in bio-oils produced by the other three metal oxide catalysts. This compound presumably forms through cyclization and condensation reactions of diverse lignin-derived intermediates generated during bond cleavage. Comparative analysis revealed substantial variations in total phenolic content among the different catalytic systems. Particularly striking was the performance of Bi₂O₃, which achieved an exceptional phenolic compound yield of 66.45 wt % -significantly surpassing the results obtained with the other three metal oxide catalysts examined in this study. Fig. 3 illustrates the influence of various metal oxide catalysts on both the production yield and compositional profile of G-type phenolic compounds derived from lignin depolymerization. Notably, three specific phenolic constituents G1 (2-methoxyphenol), G2 (creosol), and G3 (vanillin) were consistently detected in significant quantities across all catalytic systems. The formation of these low molecular weight phenolic compounds can be attributed to the unique properties of the supercritical ethanol reaction medium, in which in situ generated hydrogen species effectively stabilize lignin-derived radicals, thereby preventing undesirable recombination and condensation reactions while promoting selective bond cleavage [38]. Bi₂O₃ catalysis achieved superior performance in lignin depolymerization, yielding a combined 21.36 wt % of G2 (creosol) and G3 (vanillin) monomers-significantly higher than other metal oxides (16.77–19.22 wt %). This performance enhancement correlates with efficient β-O-4 bond cleavage, as evidenced by the positive relationship between vanillin yield and bond cleavage efficiency [34,39]. The produced phenolics exhibit distinct value propositions: creosol demonstrates exceptional antioxidant/antimicrobial capacity, whereas vanillin exhibits unique thermomechanical properties ideal for material applications [40,41]. This outstanding catalytic efficiency suggests that Bi₂O₃ possesses superior capability for facilitating lignin depolymerization while minimizing side reactions that could lead to product degradation or polymerization. 3.2.3 Effects on reaction process components The catalytic depolymerization of lignin involves a dynamic balance between the original biopolymer, transient intermediates, radical species, and final decomposition products within a unified reaction environment. SEM observations of lignin during metal oxide-catalyzed processes reveal significant morphological evolution, as illustrated in Fig. 4 . These structural transformations manifest as surface irregularities and porous architectures-physical evidence of carbonaceous residue formation during bond cleavage, where the combined solvent effects of ethanol and formic acid facilitate lignin breakdown while generating gaseous CO₂ that contributes to pore development [42]. In supercritical ethanol systems, alkaline lignin undergoes distinctive phase behavior characterized by the concurrent formation and disintegration of micrometer-scale spherical structures (1–5 μm diameter). This dynamic equilibrium between microsphere generation and depolymerization occurs at rates substantially lower than repolymerization kinetics, leading to progressive coalescence of unreacted spheres into larger aggregates [26]. Comparative analysis demonstrates that alternative metal oxide catalysts tend to generate agglomerated structures through either particle stacking (CeO₂, Co₃O₄) or fusion-induced growth (NiO). These configurations impede efficient lignin breakdown by restricting reagent diffusion, promoting repolymerization, and reducing active surface area availability-factors that collectively diminish bio-oil yields and product quality. Notably, Bi₂O₃ catalysis induces markedly different morphological outcomes, producing uniformly distributed submicron spheres (0.2–1 μm) that indicate effective disruption of lignin's macromolecular network. This enhanced dispersion minimizes intermediate aggregation, promotes reactant accessibility, and facilitates radical-mediated bimolecular interactions that drive selective phenolic compound formation [43]. The observed size reduction correlates with improved depolymerization efficiency, as constrained particle dimensions enhance mass transfer while suppressing recombination pathways. The lignin and solid residues can reflect the effects of different metal oxides on the depolymerization process of alkali lignin. Fig. 5 shows the FT-IR spectra of alkali lignin and solid residues obtained under the catalysis of different metal oxides, and also shows the FT-IR spectra of alkali lignin and solid residues catalyzed by Bi2O3 under the optimum condition. While the solid residues from various catalytic systems exhibit similar infrared absorption patterns, notable intensity variations in characteristic peaks reveal distinct reaction pathways. According to the characteristic IR peak data, the peak at 3430 cm-1 corresponds to the stretching vibration of the -OH group in the phenolic and aliphatic structures of lignin, and the absorption peaks at 2928 cm-1 and 2838 cm-1 correspond to the CH stretching vibration of -CH2 and –OCH3, which are significantly reduced in area and the intensity of the absorption of the functional groups compared with that of the unreacted lignin, suggesting that the –OCH3 was greatly consumed during the reaction [44,45]; The area of the peaks at 2928 cm⁻¹ in the optimal state is significantly smaller than that under the catalysis of Bi₂O₃ for 2 h, suggesting that the -CH2 functional group was consumed during the reaction.1592 cm-1, 1509 cm-1, 1456 cm-1 and 632 cm-1 are attributed to the lignin aryls. The absorption peaks at 1592 cm-1, 1509 cm-1, 1456 cm-1 and 632 cm-1 are attributed to the stretching vibration of the lignin aromatic ring [46], and the absorption peak at 1384 cm-1 is attributed to the vibration of the lilac-based unit. The absorption peaks at 1216 cm⁻¹, 1268 cm⁻¹, and 1042 cm⁻¹ are attributed to CO stretching vibrations in guaiacyl units. Notably, the intensity of these peaks under Bi₂O₃ catalysis was significantly weaker compared to other metal oxide catalysts. This observation indicates that the Lewis acid sites in Bi₂O₃ preferentially attack the ether oxygen atoms in β-O-4 linkages, leading to CO bond cleavage and the formation of phenoxide intermediates - a mechanism confirmed by the attenuation of these characteristic FTIR peaks [47]. These results demonstrate that Bi₂O₃ more effectively facilitates ether bond cleavage, thereby promoting lignin depolymerization into guaiacyl phenols [48]. The absorption peaks at 1145 cm-1 are attributed to the deformation of the CH surface of the guaiacyl unit, and these peaks are weakened in the residue with the increase of the reaction time, and the absorption intensity of the Bi2O3-catalyzed absorption at 1145 cm-1 is very strong in the optimum state, which suggests that a large amount of G-type phenolics compounds are produced from the lignin through the reaction. This also corresponds to the decrease in the area of some absorption peaks during the reaction process [49]. 3.3 Effects of different conditions on Bi2O3-catalyzed depolymerization of lignin 3.3.1 Interactive effects of temperature, time and catalyst amount Using Design Expert 13 software, seventeen sets of three-factor and three-level experiments were designed with Y (bio-oil yield) as the response value and A (temperature), B (reaction time), and C (additive amount) as the experimental factors. The experiments were designed according to the BBD principle for RSM. The specific experimental design scheme is shown in Table 1, and the ranges of these factors were determined based on previous research on lignin-catalyzed depolymerization experiments. The experimental results are shown in Table 2, and the results of the regression model's analysis of variance are shown in Table 3. Fig. 6 presents the RSM analysis examining the combined effects of three critical parameters-reaction temperature, duration, and catalyst loading-on bio-oil production. The three-dimensional plots reveal distinct patterns of interaction between these variables. From Fig. 6(a), it can be observed that the initial phase (0–4 h) showed limited bio-oil generation regardless of temperature elevation from 180 °C to 240 °C. Significant synergistic effects emerged after 4 h, particularly at 220 °C. During the intermediate period (5–7 h), achieving equivalent yields required progressively lower temperatures as duration increased, demonstrating time-dependent reaction acceleration. Conversely, extended durations (7–10 h) necessitated higher temperatures for comparable yields, suggesting thermal dominance in later stages. Fig. 6(b) shows that bio-oil production exhibited a biphasic response to catalyst concentration. Optimal yields occurred within the 4–14 % range, where increasing temperature consistently enhanced output. Beyond 14 %, excessive catalyst loading paradoxically suppressed depolymerization despite temperature elevation, indicating potential active site saturation or inhibitory effects at high concentrations. As can be seen from Fig. 6(c), the elliptical contour plots confirm strong interactive effects between reaction duration and additive amount. Maximum bio-oil production was achieved at the optimized conditions of 6.75 h reaction time with 5 % catalyst loading, representing the global optimum within the tested parameter space. The results reveal that reaction kinetics progress from initial kinetic limitations through time-dependent intermediate phases to thermally-driven late-stage conversions, with catalyst performance showing non-linear concentration effects, all requiring careful parameter optimization for yield maximization. The RSM optimization successfully identified the delicate equilibrium between these competing factors, with Bi₂O₃ demonstrating superior catalytic efficiency at lower loadings compared to conventional metal oxide catalysts. Meanwhile, the optimal process for bio-oil yield was obtained according to the model within the three-factor range with bio-oil response value as Y: reaction temperature was 234.01 °C, reaction time was 6.75 h, catalyst addition was 5 %, and the model predicted the highest bio-oil yield of 77.04 wt %. In order to verify the accuracy of the model, three sets of parallel experiments were carried out according to the above optimal process conditions [50]. The experimental results were 77.13 wt %, 77.28 wt % and 76.98 wt %, respectively, with an average yield of 77.13 wt %, which matched well with the model predictions and verified the validity of the developed model. 3.3.2 Effects of formic acid The decomposition of formic acid under supercritical conditions leads to in situ H2 production, which can provide a source of hydrogen for lignin depolymerization [51–53]. Fig. 7 shows the effect of the addition of formic acid solution on lignin depolymerization. The reaction was carried out at 240 °C for 10 h. It can be seen that the highest recovery of lignin (19.8 wt %) was achieved under no - additive (no catalyst, no formic acid solution) conditions, and only 40.24 wt % of bio-oil was obtained, which indicates that the depolymerization capacity of lignin under the current reaction conditions is only dependent on the hydrogen donor and its own reaction under temperature conditions. When the formic acid solution was added, the bio-oil yield increased to 61.36 wt %,and when the catalyst Bi₂O₃ was added, the bio-oil yield increased to 48.43 wt %, respectively. This suggests that both formic acid and the catalyst can promote the catalytic hydrogenolysis of lignin to some extent. Compared with the addition of catalyst only, the coke yield decreased by 13.95 wt % and the bio-oil yield increased by 12.93 wt % with the addition of formic acid only, confirming its dual role as hydrogen donor and repolymerization inhibitor [54]. When the formic acid solution and the catalyst acted in conjunction, the bio-oil yield increased to 68.48 wt %, and the coke yield was 29.92 wt %. Compared with adding only formic acid, the bio-oil yield increased by 7.12 wt %. The synergistic effect of the two is more conducive to the complete depolymerization of lignin into bio-oil [55]. 3.3.3 Reusability of the catalyst In this subsection, the effect of recycled catalysts on the catalytic depolymerization of lignin for the preparation of bio-oil was investigated to assess the stability and activity of the catalysts. As shown in Fig. 8 , after five cycles, the catalyst Bi₂O₃ still remained relatively active in lignin hydrogenolysis. With the decrease of Bi₂O₃ activity, the lignin could not be completely hydrogenolyzed, and the by-products accumulated. As a result, the generation of carbon residue gradually increased, the bio-oil yield gradually decreased, the amount of unreacted lignin increased, and the conversion rate decreased. When the catalyst was recycled for the third time, the number and nature of catalyst active sites tended to be stable, which could stabilize the catalytic depolymerization of lignin. The yields of bio-oil and carbon residue in the reaction gradually stabilized. 4 Conclusions Comparative analysis showed that Bi₂O₃ had excellent catalytic performance with 66.45 wt % phenolic yield, which was significantly better than other metal oxides. In particular, the combined yield of G2 (creosol) and G3 (vanillin) monomers reached 21.36 wt % due to the unique ability of Bi₂O₃ to control the dispersion of the substrate-product, and selectively cleave β-O-4 bonds while suppressing intermediate recombination. The optimized Bi₂O₃-formic acid synergistic system achieved peak efficiency at 234.01 °C with 6.75 h reaction duration and 5 % catalyst amount, yielding 77.04 wt % bio-oil. This represents a 36.80 wt % improvement over non-catalytic conditions, achieved through three complementary mechanisms: formic acid-mediated hydrogen donation and coke suppression, Bi₂O₃-induced spatial separation of reactive intermediates and acid-base-catalyzed selective bond cleavage. Furthermore, bismuth catalysts demonstrated exceptional operational stability, maintaining > 90 % initial activity through five consecutive reaction cycles. The thermal robustness (≤ 500 °C) and chemical inertness of bismuth oxides suggest potential for industrial-scale implementation. Future development could focus on hybrid catalytic systems combining bismuth with transition metals to enhance both conversion efficiency and phenolic selectivity. coredata.dc:description: Catalytic hydrogenolysis of lignin to high value-added chemicals has been a hot topic in recent years. Metal oxide catalysts are prepared by the co-precipitation method. Bi₂O₃ exhibits unique advantages in catalyzing lignin depolymerization for bio-oil production, demonstrating high selectivity in cleaving ether bonds within the lignin structure.The purpose of this study is to compare the performance of bismuth metal with several other metals for the catalytic hydrogenolysis of lignin. Based on the response surface methodology (RSM), the catalytic abilities of several metal oxides for the preparation of bio-oil from lignin under optimal conditions were determined as follows: NiO (77.18 wt %) ≈ Bi₂O₃ (77.04 wt %) > Co₃O₄ (71.12 wt %) > CeO₂ (61.39 wt %); However, comparable performance can be achieved with significantly lower amounts of Bi₂O₃ catalysts. Gas chromatography-mass spectrometry (GC–MS) analysis demonstrated that Bi₂O₃-catalyzed product contained 66.45 wt % yield of phenolic compounds, significantly higher than those catalyzed by other metal oxides. Notably, the combined yield of creosol (G2) and vanillin (G3) reached 21.36 wt %, representing the highest value among all catalysts tested. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) spectra showed that the components in the lignin depolymerization system were uniformly dispersed in the presence of Bi₂O₃ catalyst, which contributed to the cleavage of ether bonds and promoted the generation of a large amount of phenolic compounds. The interactive effects of temperature, time and catalyst dosage on the catalytic hydrogenolysis of lignin and the effect of the addition of the hydrogen donor, formic acid, on the depolymerization were also analyzed. Finally, the recoverability test showed that the catalytic performance of Bi₂O₃ remained active and stable after five consecutive recovery runs.
